title: Developing Self-Compassion
description: Learn to treat yourself with the same kindness you would offer to a good friend

questions.prompt: Describe a situation where you've been self-critical recently:
questions.placeholder: Example: I made a mistake at work and called myself stupid

questions.prompt: What exactly did you say to yourself in this situation?
questions.placeholder: Example: I can't believe I did that. I'm so incompetent.

questions.prompt: Now imagine a good friend came to you with the exact same situation. What would you say to them?
questions.placeholder: Example: Everyone makes mistakes sometimes. One error doesn't define your abilities.

questions.prompt: Notice the difference between how you spoke to yourself and how you would speak to a friend. Why do you think this difference exists?
options: I hold myself to higher standards than others
I've been taught that self-criticism motivates improvement
I don't believe I deserve the same kindness I give others
I never realized how differently I treat myself

questions.prompt: How difficult is it for you to be kind to yourself when you struggle or fail?
Self-compassion means making excuses for mistakes or avoiding responsibility.
Write a compassionate message to yourself about the situation you described earlier:
questions.placeholder: Example: I'm human and making mistakes is part of learning. I can acknowledge this error while still being kind to myself.

questions.prompt: Which is a component of self-compassion according to Dr. Kristin Neff's research?
options: Common humanity (recognizing that suffering is part of shared human experience)
Self-improvement (constantly working to fix your flaws)

questions.prompt: Think of a small, specific way you could show yourself kindness today:
questions.placeholder: Example: Taking a short break, preparing a nice meal, speaking to myself gently

questions.prompt: After completing this exercise, how valuable do you think self-compassion could be for your wellbeing?
